Trial_Design.evidence: Patients with periampullary tumours who underwent open pancreatoduodenectomy were randomly allocated

Participants.evidence: Patients with periampullary tumours who underwent open pancreatoduodenectomy

Intervention.evidence: randomly allocated to either the no-touch approach or the superior mesenteric artery approach

Objective.evidence: The aim of this study was to assess two pancreatoduodenectomy approaches

Method_Outcome.evidence: Primary outcomes were the intraoperative number of circulating tumour cells and cluster mobilization

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: randomly allocated to either the no-touch approach or the superior mesenteric artery approach

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 101 patients with periampullary tumours were randomized

Number_Analysed.evidence: 63 patients with pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (34 in the superior mesenteric artery group and 29 in the no-touch group) were analysed

Result_Outcome.evidence: median metastasis disease-free survival (12.4 (interquartile range 6.1–not reached) months in the superior mesenteric artery group and 18.1 (interquartile range 12.1–not reached) months in the no-touch group; P = 0.730)
